File.Title: Prefrontal Cortical Projections to the Cholinergic Neurons in the Basal Forebrain
File.Authors: RONALD P.A. GAYKEMA, ROB VAN WEEGHEL, LOUIS B. HERSH,

Abstract.S: The prefrontal cortex (PFC) projections to the basal forebrain cholinergic cell groups in the medial septum (MS), vertical and horizontal limbs of the diagonal band of Broca (VDB and HDB), and the magnocellular basal nucleus (MBN) in the rat were investigated by anterograde transport of Phaseolus vulgaris leuco-agglutinin (PHA-L) combined with acetylcholinesterase (AChE) histochemistry or choline acetyltransferase (ChAT) immunocytochemistry.
The experiments revealed rich PHA-Glabeled projections to discrete parts of the basal forebrain cholinergic system (BFChS) essentially originating from all prefrontal areas investigated.

The PFC afTerents to the BFChS display a topographic organization, such that medial prefrontal areas project to the MS, VDB, and the medial part of the HDB, whereas the orbital and agranular insular areas predominantly innervate the HDB and MBN, respectively.

Since the recurrent BFChS projection to the prefrontal cortex is arranged according to a similar topography, the relationship between the BFChS and the prefrontal cortex is characterized by reciprocal connections.

Furthermore, tracer injections in the PFC resulted in anterograde labeling of numerous "en passant" and terminal boutons apposing perikarya and proximal dendrites of neurons in the basal forebrain, which were stained for the cholinergic marker enzymes.

These results indicate that prefrontal cortical afferents make direct synaptic contacts upon the cholinergic neurons in the basal forebrain, although further analysis at the electron microscopic level will be needed to provide conclusive evidence.

Introduction.S: The mammalian basal forebrain contains a continuous string of magnocellular cholinergic neurons being the major source of cholinergic innervation of the cerebral cortex, hippocampus, amygdala, and olfactory bulb.

In the rodent brain, accumulations of these cholinergic neurons are present in the medial septum (MS) and the nuclei of the diagonal band of Broca (DB), forming the rostra1 portion of the basal forebrain cholinergic system (BFChS).

More caudally, the cholinergic neurons are distributed throughout the ventral pallidum (W), substantia innominata (SI), and the ventral, medial, and caudal segments of the globus pallidus (GP), collectively termed the magnocellular basal nucleus (MBN) (Sofroniew et al., '82; Mesulam et al., '83b; Cuello and Sofroniew, '84).

In the primate brain, the main bulk of the magnocellular, cortically projecting, cholinergic neurons are aggregated in the infrapallidal basal nucleus of Meynert (Mesulam et al., '83a; Saper and Chelimsky, '84).

Considerable knowledge has been gained on the overall topography of the cortical projections of the BFChS by using retrograde and anterograde tracing with horseradish peroxidase or tritiated amino acids (Mesulam et al., '83a,b; Lamour et al., '84; Rye et al., '84; Saper, '84; Woolf et al., '84).

Furthermore, detailed information on the topographic arrangement of the basal forebrain-cortical/hippocampal projection, and on the patterns of termination in the cortex and hippocampus, was obtained with anterograde tracing of the rat BFChS by using the plant lectin Phaseolus vulgaris leuco-agglutinin (PHA-L) (Luiten et al., '85, '87; Nyakas et al., '87; Gaykema et al., '90).
Next to the wealth of data on the efferent connections of the BFChS, a flow of information on the sources of afferent input to the cholinergic neurons has started to emerge.
Axonal transport studies in several animal species have provided information on projections from a number of brain areas that terminate in the cholinergic cell areas in the basal forebrain.

Summarizing these results, it can be concluded that the BFChS receives input from brainstem monoaminergic systems (Semba et al., '88; Vertes et al., '88; Jones and Cuello, '89) but also from cortical, hippocampal, and amygdaloid regions (Jones et al., '76; Lemann and Saper, '85; Mesulam and Mufson '84; Russchen et al., '85; Irle and Markowitsch, '86; Aggleton et al., '871, and in turn relays this information flow to the cortical mantle via the cholinergic projection.

The cortical relationship of the forebrain cholinergic projection neurons is therefore most likely not limited to its efferent projections but is also determined by a recurrent cortical afferent input.

Ample evidence has been gained that the cortical input to the BFChS particularly arises from several limbic and paralimbic cortices based on studies in rodents (Lemann and Saper, '85), carnivores, and primates (Mesulam and Mufson, '84; Russchen et al., '85; Irle and Markowitsch, '86; Aggleton et al., '87).
These findings are also essential for our understanding of the involvement of the BFChS in neurodegenerative processes and the deficiencies in information processing in Alzheimer's disease.

This disease is consistently characterized by a severely decreased cortical cholinergic innervation and a concomitant degeneration of neurons within the basal nucleus of Meynert (Whitehouse et al., '82; Coyle et al., '83; Saper et al., '85) and by the development of neuritic plaques and neurofibrillary tangles in particular within the limbic and paralimbic cortices (Hyman et al., '84; Pearson et al., '85; Rogers and Morrison, '85).
The aim of the present investigation is therefore to examine the organization of the cortical feedback to the BFChS in more detail.

In this work we focussed on the overall distribution of the limbic prefrontal cortical projections to the basal forebrain using the PHA-L anterograde tracing method (Gerfen and Sawchenko, '84) in combination with staining of the cholinergic cells by acetylcholinesterase (AChE) pharmacohistochemistry or choline acetyltransferase (ChAT) immunohistochemistry at the light microscopic level.

Methods.S: MATERIALSANDMETHODS
PHA-L antemgrade tracing
Thirty-four young adult, male Wistar rats weighing between 250 and 300 g received injections of PHA-L in the various subdivisions of the prefrontal cortex.
The animals were anesthetized with sodium pentobarbital (40 mg/kg b.w., i.p.) and Hypnorm (Duphar, 0.4 mlkg b.w., i.m.1 and placed in a stereotaxic apparatus.

PHA-L (Vector, 2.5% in Tris-buffered saline, pH 7.4) was delivered iontophoretically through bevelled glass micropipettes (diameter 15-20 km) by a positive current of 6 FA which was generated by a Midgard CS3 constant current source.
The delivery lasted for 30 minutes in a 7-seconds-on/7-seconds-off cycle.
The injection coordinates were calculated according to the rat cortex stereotaxic atlas of Zilles ('85).
Seven to ten days after the PHA-L delivery, one group of ten animals received an intramuscular injection of diisopropylfluorophosphate (DFP, Sigma Chemical Co., St.
Louis, MO), dissolved in arachis oil (O.l%), at a dose of 1.5 mVkg b.w. 5 hours prior to sacrifice for the pharmacohistochemical demonstration of AChE-rich neurons (Butcher et al., '75).

These animals were then deeply anesthetized with sodium pentobarbital (70 mg/kg b.w., ip.) and perfused through the heart with saline followed by a mixture of 2.5% glutaraldehyde (GA) and 0.5 paraformaldehyde (PF) in 0.1 M phosphate buffer (PB).
The other 24 animals were perfused without DFP pretreatment.
Their brains were fixed by perfusion with 4% PF in 0.1 M PB for the simultaneous, immunohistochemical staining of PHA-L and ChAT.
The sections were serially collected in vials containing 10 mM phosphate-buffered saline (PBS, pH 7.4).
Single PHA-L irnmunehemishy
Every third section of the forebrain was processed for single PHA-L staining by peroxidase immunohistochemistry as previously described (Luiten et al., '87; '88).

Interrupted by washings in Tris-buffered saline (TBS, pH 7.4), the sections were subsequently incubated in rabbit antiPHA-L (DAKO, 1:2,000) for 24-72 hours at 4"C, goat anti-rabbit IgG (TAGO, 1:50) for 4 hours at room temperature, and rabbit peroxidase anti-peroxidase complex (PAP) (Dako, 1:400) for overnight at 4°C.
All antibodies were diluted in TBS containing 0.5% Triton X-100 (TBS-T).
The sections were then processed in DAB (0.04%) and H,O, (0.01%) in Tris-HC1, pH 7.6, and a selection of them was counterstained with cresyl violet.
PHA-L immunocytmhem;stwcombinedwith AChE histochemistry
The following procedure was applied for the ten DFPtreated cases.
Prior to the immunostaining of PHA-L (see above), selected sections, containing the basal forebrain cholinergic cell groups, were stained for AChE using silvernitrate intensification.

The sections were incubated in an sodium acetate-buffered solution (50 mM, pH 5.0) containing 2 mM copper sulphate and 10 mM glycine, to which acetylthiocholine-iodide (Merck, 4 mM) and the nonspecific esterase-inhibitor ethopropazine (Sigma Chemical Co., St.
Louis, MO, 0.2 mM) was added.
The sections were subsequently reacted in sodium sulphide (l%, pH adjusted to 7.8) and silver nitrate (1%) for 40 seconds each, to reveal black staining of the AChE-rich neurons.
After thorough washing in distilled water, the sections were transferred to TBS and processed for PHA-L immunocytochemistry.
This latter procedure was performed as for the single PHA-L immunolabeling.
Combined immunohbeljngof PHA-L andChAT
A monoclonal rat anti-ChAT antibody (Boehringer, Mannheim, FRG) and a polyclonal goat anti-ChAT antiserum (Bruce et al., '85) were used to visualize ChAT immunoreactivity.
Every third section containing the basal forebrain was processed for double-immunolabeling of ChAT and PHA-L.

The sections were subsequently incubated in pooled primary antisera, i.e., rabbit anti-PHA-L (Dako, 1:5,000) and rat anti-ChAT (1:lOO) for 48-72 hours at 4"C, and in a mixture of swine anti-rabbit (Nordic, 1:50) and goat antirat IgG (Zymed, 1:lOO) for 4 hours at room temperature, all diluted in TBS-T.

Thereafter, the PHA-Glabeled fibers were stained black by incubation of the sections in rabbit PAP (Dako, 1:500) followed by a reaction with nickelenhanced DAB (Ni-DAB), according to a procedure described by Luiten et al. ('88).
The reaction consisted of 0.4% Nickel ammonium sulphate, 0.015% DAB, and 0.01% H,O, in Tris-HC1 (pH = 8.0).
The sections were then exposed to rat PAP (Sera-lab, 1200) for 4 hours and processed in DAB to reveal brown staining of the cholinergic cell bodies.
A similar, adapted protocol was followed for labeling ChAT using the polyclonal antibody.
Here, sections were incubated in a mixture of goat anti-ChAT (1:1,000) and rabbit anti-PHA-L (1:5,000), followed by a mixture of swine anti-goat (TAGO, 1:50) and swine anti-rabbit (1:50).
Black PHA-L-immunostaining was performed with rabbit PAP and reaction in Ni-DAB.
Brown ChAT-immunolabeling was completed by using goat PAP (DAKO, 1:500) and processing in DAB.
Comments on the nomenclature
In the following account, the parcellation of the prefrontal cortex (PFC) used in this paper is largely adapted from Zilles ('85).
The nomenclature of the medial PFC sectors, however, is derived from Krettek and Price ('78) and from Van Eden and Uylings ('85).
The ventral and lateral parts of the PFC comprise the orbital and sulcal, agranular insular cortical areas, and are parcellated according to Zilles ('85).
With regard to the ventral and ventrolateral orbital cortical areas (VO and VLO), this delineation is slightly different from the nomenclature as proposed by Groenewegen ('88).

In this study, the PFC covers a larger area than the "mediodorsal projection cortex" as originally defined by Leonard ('69), and forms an uninterrupted area around the rostral pole (Uylings and Van Eden, '90).
The medial prefrontal areas subjected to investigation are the prelimbic (PL), infralimbic (IL), dorsal peduncular cortex (DPC), and the medial orbital (MO) cortices.
The lateral prefrontal areas studied include the ventrolateral and lateral orbital cortex (VLO and LO), and the dorsal agranular insular cortex (AId).
The ventral agranular insular cortex has been considered as a caudal extension of the LO (Van Eden and Uylings, '85) and is not separately mentioned in this study.

The nomenclature of the cholinergic nuclei in the basal forebrain is generally derived from Carlsen et al. ('85) and Zaborszky et al. ('86) with respect to the parcellation of the ventral pallidum (VP), substantia innominata (SI), and the nuclei of the diagonal band of Broca (DB).
The area that is often called the magnocellular preoptic region (e.g., Swanson, '76) forms the intermediate and lateral parts of the horizontal limb of the diagonal band of Broca (HDB) in this study.
The vertical limb of the diagonal band of Broca (VDB) comprises the angular part of the diagonal band nuclei (cf.
Gaykema et al., '90).

Results.S: RESULTS
Survey of the PHA - L experiments
In twenty - five cases , the PHA - L deposits involved the deep cortical layers and resulted in abundant labeled PFC efferents in various foreand mid - brain areas .
The location and extent of the injection sites are shown in Figure 1.

Next to the distribution of the PHA - Glabeled neurons , two other criteria were used to determine whether the PHA - G labeled neurons are confined to a single or two adjacent cytoarchitectonically defined cortical areas : A ) the distribution of the crossed cortico - cortical projection , which is densest in the contralateral homotypic cortex ( Fig . 2a , b ) , and B ) the distribution of the labeled efferents in the thalamus .

Thirteen injections were centered in the lateral PFC , of which ten injections were largely confined to the dorsal agranular insular cortex ( AId ) ( RG18, RG138, RJ2, RW8, and RW33 ) , posterior agranular insular cortex ( AIp ) ( RJ5 ) , lateral orbital cortex ( RG137, RJ1, and RW9 ) , or ventrolateral orbital cortex ( RG136 ) .
One injection covered both VLO and LO (RG19).
In two cases , PHA - L - labeled neurons were distributed in the AId and adjacent frontal neocortex ( RG14 and RG20 ) .

Seven of the twelve medial PFC injections were confined to one defined area , i . e . , prelimbic ( PL ) ( RJ6, RW5, and RWlZ ) , infralimbic ( IL ) ( RW19 and RW22 ) , or dorsal peduncular cortex ( DPC ) ( RG135 and RW16 ) .
In five other cases , more than one cortex area was involved ( RG15 and RG17 : PL and IL ; RW23 and RW31 : DPC and IL ; RG16 : MO , IL , and DPC ) .
Another three injections were placed in the taenia tecta just ventral to the MO ( RG13 ) or the DPC ( RJ3 and RW32j .
General pattern of the PFC efferents

PHA - Glabeled neurons in all PFC subdivisions gave rise to a massively labeled assembly of fascicles entering the anterior head of the striatum , traversing it in a caudal direction , and fusing with the ventromedial edge of the capsula interna ( ic ) ( Figs . 3E , 4E ) .
From the ic , part of the labeled fascicles continued in the inferior thalamic peduncle .
Other labeled fibers spreaded towards preoptic , hypothalamic , and amygdaloid areas .

Depending on the PFC sector injected, a group of PHA-Llabeled fascicles appeared within a particular restricted part of the ventral half of the caudate putamen (CPu) just dorsal to the anterior commissure (Figs. 3B,C, 4B,C).

In addition , restricted parts of the CPu , accumbens nucleus ( Acb ) , fundus striati ( FSt ) , cell bridges of the ventral striatum ( CB ) , and olfactory tubercle ( Tu ) contained dense networks of labeled projections , demonstrating a regional organization of the corticostriatal inputs .

The medial prefrontal projections are mainly aimed at the medial parts of the CPu and Acb , the FSt , and the entire mediolateral extent of the CB and Tu in an irregular , patchy pattern ( Fig . 3 ) .

Corticostriatal inputs from more lateral ( orbital and insular ) areas of the PFC are concentrated in progressively more lateral aspects of the ventral half of the CPu , Acb , and the ventral striatum ( including the Tu ) ( Fig . 4 ) .

PHA - L - labeled projections of the medial and lateral prefrontal areas were distributed in a variety of cortical and subcortical striatal , preoptic , thalamic , hypothalamic , and brainstem areas , generally in accordance with previously described results from anterograde tracing of PFC efferents in rat ( Beckstead , ' 79 ; Groenewegen , ' 88 ) and cat ( Room et Distribution of the AChEand CUT - positive Perikarya

The distribution of the AChE - stained cell bodies and that of the ChAT - immunoreactive neurons in the basal forebrain were observed to be generally similar and in concordance with previously published data ( Eckenstein and Sofroniew , ' 83 ; Levey et al . , ' 83 ; Wainer et al . , ' 84 ) .
The AChE-stained perikarya contained black granular reaction product with variable intensity (Fig. 2d,e).

A continuous string of strongly AChE - stained somata and , in a nearly identical fashion , ChAT - immunoreactive cell bodies was present in the MS , VDB , HDB , subcommissural ventral pallidum W ) , sublenticular SI , and the ventromedial and caudal globus pallidus ( GP ) .
Besides,AChEand ChATpositive neurons were similarly distributed throughout the striatal areas, i.e., the CPu, FSt, CB, Tu, and Acb.

Simultaneous PHA - L and AChE staining revealed brown fibers and presynaptic endings together with black , granular staining of neuronal profiles ( Fig . 2d , e ) .
A disadvantage of the latter method is the irregular appearance of the black AChE reaction product yielding vague contours of the cell bodies and proximal dendrites.

Following tracer injections in the various parts of the PFC , considerable numbers of fibers became labeled which were present in discrete parts of the basal forebrain regions containing the magnocellular cholinergic neurons .

The prefrontal afferents in these cholinergic cell areas in the basal forebrain are topographically organized related to the PFC area of origin , as is the case with the corticostriatal projections ( cf .
Figs. 3,4).

The PHA - L injections in the medial prefrontal areas , i . e . , the prelimbic , infralimbic , dorsal peduncular, and medial orbital cortices revealed generally similar distributions of anterograde labeling in the basal forebrain cholinergic nuclei .
As will be described below, differences between labeling patterns from PL, IL, DPC, and MO are reflected mainly in variation in density of projections.
In general , more ventrally placed injections labeled denser terminal networks throughout the MS , VDB , and HDB .

The only profound difference betweenthe anterograde labeling resulting from injections into the PL and IL on the one hand and the DPC on the other hand is the remarkably dense terminal field in the medial aspects of the lateral septum .
This lateral septum projection becomes labeled after PHA - L injections in the DPC only ( compare Fig . 3B , C with Fig . 6A , B ) .

PHA - L injections into more lateral ( orbital and insular ) parts of the PFC resulted in anterograde labeling of fiber networks covering progressively more lateral parts of the basal forebrain cholinergic nuclei.
There is, however, a considerable overlap of the projection fields from neighbouring areas of the PFC.
The projections of each PFC sector to the BFChS will be described in detail with reference to representative cases.
In each of these cases , PHA - L - labeled neurons were largely confined to a single topographically defined PFC area .
Prelimbic cortex (case RJ6).

TTE.S: FollowingPHA - L injections in the PL, a massive number of axons becomes labeled running into the forceps minor of the corpus callosum .
Here, these fibers become arranged into tiny fascicles and traverse the medial CPu just dorsal to the anterior commissure in a caudal direction (Fig. 3B,C).
Along their course , they give off a dense plexus of fibers terminating in the medial CPu , FSt , and in restricted parts of the Tu .

After merging with the anteromedial segment of the ic , a contingent of labeled axons turn ventrally just caudal to the crossing of the anterior commissure and spread into the VP , the medial part of the sublenticular SI , the lateral preoptic area ( LPO ) , and the medial part of the horizontal limb of the diagonal band ( HDBm ) ( Fig . 3B , C ) .

Particularly in the LPO and HDBm , the fibers branch frequently and show numerous varicosities , which approach the most medially distributed AChE - containing or ChAT - immunopositive neurons in the VP and HDBm .

A small number of labeled fibers runs into the anterior pole of the septal area and course through the medial part of the lateral septum ( LSm ) , MS , and vertical limb of the diagonal band ( VDB ) , where they arborize into branches bearing varicosities ( Fig . 3B ) .
These fibers intermingle with the CUT - labeled neuronal profiles in the lateral part of the MS and in the VDB in a similar fashion as , but less numerous than the efferents from the DPC do ( cf .

Results.S: Figs. 5a,b, 6).

TTE.S: Infralimbic cortex (case RW19).
As is the case for the PL , the infralimbic prefrontal efferents reach the basal forebrain via the anterior septal pole and via the striatal fiber bundles .
The pattern of termination in the striatum , however , is slightly different from that of the PL .
Dense clusters of terminating fibers are present in the medial halves of the Acb , FSt , CB , and Tu , but not in the CPu .
A larger number of projections to the LSm , lateral part of the MS , and the W B became labeled than after PL injections .

Numerous fibers traverse along the AChE / ChAT - containing neurons in the MS and VDB giving off terminal branches which appose the cholinergic profiles in a nearly identical fashion as the DPC efferents do ( cf .
Figs. 5a, 6a,b).

Another massive group of labeled axons emanates from the anteromedial segment of the capsula interna and runs ventrally to terminate densely in the medial parts of the VP and HDB ( Fig . 3 ) , and ventromedially to innervate the lateral and medial divisions of the preoptic area .
As is the case after tracer injections in the DPC , numerous PHA - G labeled endings make intimate contacts to ChAT - positive cell bodies or dendrites in the HDBm ( Fig . 6C , D ) .

More caudally , fibers spread into the medial part of the sublenticular SI reaching the ventral surface of the brain just lateral to the supraoptic nucleus , along which route they approach only the most medially located cholinergic neurons ( Fig . 6D ) .
Dorsal peduncular cortex (case RG135).

The basal forebrain projections originating in the DPC differ from those emanating from the IL mainly with respect to a remarkably dense terminal field in a restricted zone of the LSm , which invade the lateral half of the MS ( Fig . 6A , B ) .
The dorsolaterally located ChAT - positive neurons of the MS and anterior pole of the VDB are embraced by the PHA - L - labeled terminal plexus ( Figs . 5b , IOb , c ) .
A small number of labeled fibers reach the cholinergic cells in the medial raphe of the MS ( Figs . 6B , 10a ) .
Like the efferents from the PL and IL , but larger in number , fibers from the DPC traverse the diagonal band area and abundantly innervate the W B and HDBm ( Figs . 5a , 6 ) .
A terminal plexus is prominent just ventral to the cholinergic cell region of the HDB and dorsal to the cell islands of Calleja in the Tu ( Fig . 6C ) .
Again , numerous PHA - L - labeled endings contact the VDB and HDBm cholinergic neuronal profiles .
A number of fibers emanating from the capsula interna turn ventrally to terminate in the medial half of the HDB .

More caudally , numerous fibers traverse the sublenticular SI , medially and ventrally passing the clusters of the MBN cholinergic neurons at some distance , whereas others run into the anterior amygdaloid nuclei and piriform cortex ( Fig . 6D ) .

Results.S: It should be noted that the striatal projections from the DPC are far more limited than those from the IL and PL and are mainly aimed at the Tu and the FSt .

TTE.S: Medial orbital cortex (case RG16).

The pattern of basal forebrain projections from the medial orbital area is highly comparable to the distribution of the DPC efferents with respect to the septal area , diagonal band nuclei , and the medial part of the SI , although the terminal plexus in the LSm is far less prominent .
In addition , there is also a strong innervation of the medial segments of both the CPu and Acb in a similar fashion as the striatal projections originating in the PL and IL , respectively .

It remains , however , to be established whether the input to the basal forebrain essentially originates in the MO , or arise from the adjacent IL , DPC , or taenia tecta , since these latter cortical areas contained some PHA - L - labeled neurons as well in this MO - injected case .
Ventrolateral orbital cortex (case RG136).
Bundles of PHA - Glabeled axons originating in the VLO course through the medial part of the ventral CPu and project intensely to circumscribed areas in the medial part of the CPu .
A contingent of VLO efferents reaches the anteromedial segment of the ic , turns ventrally into the VP , and terminates abundantly in the medial and intermediate parts of the HDB ( Fig . 7C ) .
Here, PHA-Glabeled endings contact many CUT-immunoreactive neuronal profiles (Fig. 1 lc).

More caudally , labeled fascicles traverse the ventromedial part of the GP and diverge into the medial aspects of the sublenticular SI and GP , where a small number of fibers reaches the MBN cholinergic cells ( Fig . 7D ) .

In the septa1 area , a small number of labeled VLO efferents runs through the LSm and MS ( Fig . 7A ) , whereas a dense plexus of fibers is present in the ventral parts of the VDB and HDBm ( Fig . 7B ) .
More caudally in the HDB , this plexus of fibers intermingle with labeled afferents emanating from the anterior pole of the internal capsule ( Fig . 7C , D ) .
Like the anterograde labeling resulting from PHA - L injections in the DPC , this axonal plexus proceeds in a zone interstitiated between the HDB and Tu ( Fig . 7C , lower side ) .
Lateral orbital cortex (case RG137).
Bundles of labeled fibers originating in the LO enter the anterior head of the CPu and traverse the central part of the ventral CPu in caudal direction .
Along this route , labeled axons run ventrally to the FSt , VP , SI , and the lateral and intermediate aspects of the HDB ( Fig . 8A - C ) .
These projections in particular give rise to abundant terminal labeling among the cholinergic cells of the lateral and intermediate aspects of the HDB ( Fig . lla , b ) .

A dense network of labeled fibers is present in a zone interstitiated in between the HDB and Tu , which continues in an anteromedial direction invading the ventral part of the caudal VDB ( Fig . 8A , B ) .
At a more caudal level , labeled axons diverge from the ventromedial aspects of the GP and the capsula interna in a ventral direction .
These fibers invade the sublenticular SI and the caudal part of the HDB, reaching the large CUT-positive neurons in these regions (Figs. 8C,D, 12c).
Dorsal agranular insular cortex ( case JR2 ) .
A contingent of fascicles of PHA - L - labeled fibers runs through the ventrolateral part of the CPu in a caudal direction and joins the ventral part of the ic ( Fig . 9C , D ) .
A dense plexus of fibers from the AId covers the FSt and the ventrolateral corner of the CPu along its entire rostrocaudal extent .
From the capsula interna , a dense group of PHA - L - labeled fibers runs ventrolaterally into the ventral part of the GP and the lateral and intermediate parts of the SI .
Here , terminal labeling was observed on the MBN cholinergic neuronal processes ( Figs . 9C , D , 12a , b ) .
Furthermore , moderate terminal labeling is present in the subcommissural VP and the lateral part of the HDB , whereas the MS , VDB , and HDBm are essentially devoid of input ( Fig . 9A , B ) .
Posterior agranular insular cortex ( case JR5 ) .

A massive bundle of labeled axons originates from the PHA - Llabeled neurons in the AIp and enters the external capsule deep to the AIp to penetrate the ventral ridge of the CPu medially and anteriorly .

A group of medially oriented fibers runs into the sublenticular SI and ventral GP , giving off short branches studded with varicosities , of which some contact the large CUT - immunopositive cells of the MBN .
The anteriorly directed labeled axons reach the FSt and lateral half of the Acb and Tu , where they branch extensively .
The HDB and subcommissural VP are only sparsely innervated by the AIp efferents.

Discussion.S: DISCUSSION

In this study the projections from the medial, orbital, and insular prefrontal cortex to the basal forebrain cholinergic nuclei were revealed by anterograde tracing with PHA-L combined with AChE histochemistry or ChAT immunocytochemistry.

PHA-L-labeled varicosities could be observed in close proximity to the magnocellular cholinergic perikarya and proximal dendrites in all regions of the BFChS, except the posterior part of the GP, which contains the most caudal population of the MBN cholinergic neurons.

The present findings are in concert with previous reports that the cholinergic nuclei in the basal forebrain receive afferent input from the prefrontal cortex (PFC) in a variety of species (rat: Beckstead '79; Lemann and Saper, '85; cat: Room et al., '85; Irle and Markowitsch, '86; monkey: Mesulam and Mufson, '84; Russchen et al., '85).
Essentially all investigated prefrontal areas contribute to the innervation of the basal forebrain cholinergic cell areas.
The present experiments clearly revealed a topographic differentiation of the afferents to the basal forebrain, related to the prefrontal area of origin.

The most striking characteristic of the topography of the PFC input to the basal forebrain cholinergic nuclei is a differential projection from the medial, ventral (orbital) and lateral (insular) areas to the anteromedial (MS, VDB, and medial part of the HDB), ventral (HDB), and the posterolateral subdivisions of the BFChS (SINBN), respectively (Fig. 13).
Merents to the MS, VDB, and the medial division of the HDB arise from the PL, IL, MO, and DPC.
The medial part of the HDB receives additional input from the VLO.
Prefrontal input to the lateral and intermediate aspects of the HDB finds its origin mainly in the orbital region (VLO and LO).

The magnocellular, cholinergic cells of the MBN in the intermediate and lateral parts of the sublenticular SI and in the ventromedial corner of the GP receive prefrontal input from the LO, AId, and AIp.

The distribution of the prefrontal efferents in the basal forebrain found in this study is highly comparable to the distribution of anterogradely transported tritiated amino acids arising from corresponding PFC areas as reported previously in various mammalian species (rat: Beckstead, '79; cat: Room et al., '85; monkey: Russchen et al., '85).

Employing retrograde tracing with wheat germ agglutinin-horseradish peroxidase conjugate (WGA-HRP), Russchen et al. ('85) demonstrated the following areas being the major prefrontal source of input to the nucleus basalis of Meynert (NBM) in the macaque: orbitofrontal (area 13), infralimbic (area 251, and the anteromedial portion of the agranular insular area.

These results are in concert with the findings of Mesulam and Mufson ('84) except for area 25, from which they did not reveal anterograde labeling in the nucleus basalis of Meynert of the rhesus monkey.
Our experiments showed that, in addition to the diagonal band nuclei, only the most anteromedial portion of the rat SI/MBN region receives some input from the infralimbic prefrontal cortex.

It is interesting to note that the topography of the PFC projection to the BFChS bears a strong resemblance to the pattern of the recurrent cholinergic basal forebrain projection to the PFC (Woolf et al., '84; Saper, '84; Luiten et al., '85; '87; Gaykema et al., '90).
Therefore, the prefrontal cortex-cholinergic basal forebrain connectivity displays a high degree of reciprocity.

The cholinergic neurons of the MS, VDB, HDB, and MBN have in common that they are embedded within the fiber bundles of the main hippocampoand cortico-fugal pathways, such as the fiber bundles of the septum and diagonal band, the medial forebrain bundle through the HDB, the capsula interna, and the ventral amygdalopetal pathway traversing the SI (Saper and Chelimsky, '84; Zaborszky et al., '86).

We indeed observed many prefrontal efferent fibers running through the BFChS reaching other targets in the preoptic region, thalamus, hypothalamus, and amygdala in concordance with previous reports (Beckstead, '79; Room et al., '85).

The presence of PHA-L-labeled presynaptic endings in all BFChS subdivisions after tracer injections in the PFC, however, strongly indicate actual projections within the basal forebrain cholinergic nuclei.
Furthermore, major contingents of labeled efferents from the PFC clearly divert from the main corticofugal pathways to specifically innervate the BFChS.
Interaction of the PFC with the magnocellular
chohergic neurons

The application of a double-labeling immunoperoxidase protocol to stain PHA-L and ChAT simultaneously has enabled us to demonstrate intercellular contacts between PHA-L-labeled varicosities and ChAT-immunoreactive neuronal cell bodies and dendrites at the light microscopic level.
The widespread pattern of PFC projections to the basal forebrain region indicates that the cholinergic cell groups only form one of the components of the PFC targets.
The light microscopic approach currently used, however, may only partially reveal the PFC-BFChS projection.
It has been reported that the dendritic profiles of the magnocellular cholinergic neurons reach a distance of approximately 600-900 km from the soma (Semba et al., '87).
These far distal dendritic branchlets were not detectably stained either with ChAT or AChE in our material.

It is well known that there is a relative paucity of afferent input to the perikarya and proximal dendrites of the cholinergic neurons, and an increase of afferent synapses on more distal regions of the dendrites (Ingham et al., '85).

Taking this into account, we may assume that afferent synaptic contacts will most likely be found on distal dendrites of the basal forebrain cholinergic neurons but cannot easily be visualized with the presently used methods.

These results strongly suggest monosynaptic control of the basal forebrain cholinergic neurons by the prefrontal cortex but will require additional electron microscopic analysis to provide conclusive evidence for a monosynaptic connection.

Applying similar techniques, Zaborszky and Cullinan ('89) recently demonstrated a monosynaptic relationship between the lateral hypothalamus and the cholinergic cells in the substantia innominata at the ultrastructural level.

The cortical input to the cholinergic cell body regions of the basal forebrain originates mainly from layer V pyramidal neurons (Russchen et d., '851, which most likely utilize excitatory amino acids (glutamate, aspartate) as neurotransmitters (Streit, '84; Campistron et al., '86; Conti et al., '87).

There is biochemical evidence indeed for a glutamatergic innervation of the septal and diagonal band nuclei (Walaas and Fonnum, '81), ventral pallidum (Fuller et al., '85), and the SINBN region (Davies et al., '841, substantiated by pharmacological evidence for the presence of glutamate receptors in the magnocellular cholinergic neurons (Wood, '86).

The sources of glutamatergic/aspartatergic fierents have only partly been revealed and may originate in other cortical areas than the PFC as well, e.g., the prepiriform, entorhinal, and temporal areas, which were identified as sources of input to the region of the basal nucleus of Meynert in the monkey (Mesulam and Mufson, '84; Russchen et al., '85).
Furthermore, Irle and Markowitsch ('86) described a periamygdaloid and perirhinal cortex projection to the SIDIBN region in the cat and monkey.

In the monkey, the medial septal and diagonal band nuclei have previously been reported to receive afferents from the hippocampal region (Mesulam and Mufson, '84; Aggleton et al., '87), which also has appeared to be the case in the rat (Gaykema et al., '89; '91).

In addition to discrete regions of the cortex, also cells in the central and basolateral nuclei of the amygdala provide efferents to the basal forebrain in various mammalian species (Krettek and Price, '78; Price and Amaral, '81; Zaborszky et al., '84; Russchen et al., '85; Irle and Markowitsch, '86; Aggleton et al., '87).
It was previously suggested that the cholinergic neurons in the rat basal forebrain receive input from all cortical areas (Saper, '84; Lemann and Saper, '85).
This suggestion was based on cortical injections of WGA-HRP resulting in anterograde axonal and retrograde soma labeling in the BFChS.

No direct projections from any of the frontal, parietal, temporal, or occipital neocortical areas to the BFChS were, however, found using PHA-L as an anterograde tracer (Gaykema and Van Eden, in preparation).
Although these findings are not in line with Saper's descriptions ('841, they are in accordance with the data obtained in primates (for review: Uylings and Van Eden, '90).
The PFC including the anterior cingulate cortex, therefore, maintains an unique position with regard to its efferent (and reciprocal) connections with the BFChS.

The present study provides evidence for an anatomical substrate of a direct and topographically differentiated prefrontal cortical influence on the basal forebrain regions and in particular their cholinergic neurons.

Part of the prefrontal control on the cholinergic cells in the basal forebrain, and thus on the recurrent cholinergic projection to the cerebral cortex, hippocampus, olfactory bulb, and amygdala, may be exerted through a direct monosynaptic loop.
The unique prefrontal cortex-basal forebrain relationship as outlined in the present study may be an important link in the complex circuitry involved in cognition.
To date, the other limbic and associational cortical feedback projections to the cholinergic basal forebrain regions have not yet been systematically investigated.

Detailed knowledge on these projections may further add to our understanding of the pathophysiological mechanisms of the cognitive decline in conditions like Alzheimer's disease that are probably transmitted through neuronal connections (Saper et al., '87; Pearson and Powell, '89), and in which the prefrontal and other association and limbic cortical areas, and the basal forebrain cholinergic neurons, have strongly been implicated.
